Planets and stars and any other individual things you choose to identify have a "beginning" and an "end". That's easy to accept. However, the stuff that makes these things are ageless. Scientists like to teach us about many principles. One of these principles is that energy and matter can neither be created nor destroyed - they merely change their state. Planets are not created out of nothing.
There is no age to the "universe" its "age" is infinite, therefore trying to measure its age is futile. The "universe" has no limit to size, its size is infinite also. Trying to measure the size of the universe is equally futile. The bothersome concept here, for us, is the concept of infinity. That is a concept that is difficult to comprehend (as far as measuring goes). We humans love to measure things. Mathematicians and scientists take the measuring thing very seriously and that's okay! We benefit by their efforts. However, there are some things that simply can not be measured. It is difficult to swallow that pill.
Simply put the universe is infinite in size and age. It has always been and will go on forever. All of these claims on putting a number to the age or size of the universe is merely a gauge on how we perceive the world around us and how we choose to measure it. It's that simple. However, some very smart people don't want to hear that!
Math and science is always evolving! Scientists gain new perspectives over time and that's okay. Don't forget that the brightest minds of the day said that the earth was at the center of everything, the sun revolved around us; also, the sun and planets moved in orbits; at first these orbits were described by the Greeks as being perfect circles; one last "known" fact was that the Earth was flat... Well, that was the "truth" advocated by the guardians of truth millennia ago, the mathematicians, scientists and philosophers -- really smart people that we believed in. Well, we "know better" today. The Earth in not at the center, planetary orbits are not perfect circles and the Earth is not flat! We "KNOW" that now. How will science and math have evolved 10, 20, 100 years from now?
Well, we will eventually catch up. Someone will come up with a reason to question the age of the universe. My gut feeling is that our understanding about the properties of light and magnetism and gravity will be "updated". The first step will be to revise the "age" of the universe. Well, it's a start! But, in reality the concept of "infinity" is something we either choose to ignore or something we simply don't understand. Regardless, it exists!
"Origins of the Universe" that is a false premise. The Big Bang THEORY is also a false premise. There is no "start" to time...Time is infinite in duration... Contraditions are very annoying!

Our bodies and our terrestrial environment are made of atoms. Atoms are ultimately made of up and down quarks, and electrons. These three elementary particles do not decay and happily exist in low energy environments.

The up quark have a positive charge equal to 2/3 of that of a proton. The electron has a charge equal to that of a proton, but negative. The down quark has a negative charge equal to 1/3 of that of the electron.

How did the Big Bang produce up quarks / down quarks / electrons in numbers having the exact ratio of 2:1:1 needed to yield a universe with no net electric charge?

Alright, I want to point out something. I see some people saying how could the Big Bang happen if there was nothing before the Big Bang? Well first, we don’t know what was before the Big Bang. There could have been something we just don’t know.

Second, humans used to believe that organic materials could come from non-organic materials. Such as maggots appearing on meat only hours after it was set out. Stuff like that. This was called spontaneous generation. Of course we know that it’s not possible now. But the thing is a guy performed an experiment. I forgot the name of the experiment or when it was performed, but an experiment was performed. This experiment replicated the condition of early Earth. Raging heat, constant lightning strikes, the works. It was probably extremely cheap to buy a house then. I’m getting if topic. When this experiment was being performed organic particles were made. This supported the theory of spontaneous generation. Of course we don’t know exactly how life on Earth was started. It could’ve been spontaneous generation or it could’ve been that life came in on a meteor.

My point is is that under certain conditions certain laws that are irrefutable today, become null and void. Something can’t come from nothing? Before the Big Bang conditions might’ve been right that something could come from nothing.

If the universe is infinite though (which according to observations, it seems to be) then you can't really assert that the big bang started from a point smaller than an atom. Rewinding back to the moment immediately after the big bang, the space between everything would be approaching zero, yet the universe is still infinite. No division of infinity yields a real number. So take one step further back and there is no space between points, yet also an infinite universe, which doesn't really make sense, hence it being called a singularity. I feel the whole "the universe started from a point smaller than an atom" is kind of a false simplification of something we don't understand, because given current knowledge it's not understandable.

NEVER think of the 'Big Bang' as an explosion. The 'Big Bang' describes when actual distances between points on any arbitrary coordinate system became a thing.

There was no distances between arbitrarily chosen points initially. This is what they call spacetime being singular, or what is commonly called a singularity. An example of a singularity is x/0, since if you anything divide by zero, all answers explode to infinity instantaneously. This is why they say everything was congealed inside an infinitely dense point.

It is not tactful to call the universe "before" the 'Big Bang' a point since there was no space between points. Points are meaningless without the concept of space, as points are an element of a space.

Our knowledge is still very limited and singularities most likely are part of presently limited theories that are concealing what is really happening at these spacetime singularities. Also know that a black hole singularity is not a point either, it is actually a rift.

The phrase "Big Bang" summarizes the most widely accepted scientific theory of how the universe developed into its present state. The evidence suggests that a period of expansion began about 13.8 billion (±200 million) years ago and has continued ever since. The actual cause of inflation has not been fully determined, although the basic model makes some predictions which have been confirmed.

Many views exist on what new physics will show about the beginning of the universe because it is still an open question. In one proposal space and time (space-time) began to exist about 13.8 billion years ago. In other proposals, the universe has inflationary periods. In yet another proposal a "multiverse" existed before our universe began. The details of what happened prior to 13.8 billion years ago (or if that even makes sense) remain to be worked out.

Many converging lines of evidence support the Big Bang model, including:

the observed expansion of the universe
the observed cosmic microwave background radiation and its anisotropies
the observed ratios of elements that are left over from the early universe
simulations involving galaxy formation
the many measurements (most of which have nothing to do with cosmology) that show that dark matter is real and not just a "fudge factor" (as some alternative theorists and creationists claim)

Note that the Big Bang theory does not attempt to describe the initial conditions or first cause of the universe. The theory merely addresses the development of the universe from its extremely dense and hot early stages into its present form. (Compare and contrast how the theory of evolution likewise does not concern itself with the origin of life on Earth; but merely with its development after its origin.) It is instructive to think of the Big Bang not as a localized explosion from which all matter moves away, but rather as a uniform expansion of space itself. An observer at any point in the universe sees the same thing: a homogeneous distribution of matter everywhere, with the more-and-more distant parts receding faster and faster.

Stop, stop, stop with that "math explains it so well" nonsense. Math describes. Precisely. It does not explain. And math doesn't even do a super-great job of transmitting knowledge with its descriptions; the only thing it's got going for it is its precision. As plenty of linguists have explained (with natural human languages) math is not a natural human language. A natural human language is how you explain things to other people. Mathematics is one way you can describe phenomenae, and it is likely the most precise way to do so. But it does not explain anything.

Also, I have the intuition that the phenomenon of "dark matter" is akin to the phenomenon of light always having the same speed regardless of the speed of its source, which befuddled physicists till Einstein came along to explain it with relativity. I don't know why the "Big Bang started as a tiny point" is perpetuated in every pop-sci description of BB. It is simply not true. There is no firm evidence that Universe is and/or was even finite at any point in time, let alone a "point".

The only accurate statement we can make is that current observable Universe (which is just a part of the whole Universe) was a very small volume very near to BB moment, something the size of proton.

Also worth mentioning that current physics can extrapolate very close to BB, but we actually can't extrapolate all the way to it. First ~10^-30 fraction of the second is still not cracked.
Asking "what happened before the Big Bang" is like asking "what's on north of the north pole"

The origin of the Big Bang is perhaps better expressed in terms of the first motion. Look at the formula for time distance and rate. Without motion the formula is undefined, thus nothing exists, no time, no space; nothing at all.
No motion means, no temperature, no radiation, no matter, no magnetism, no gravity; no life as we know it. Its all undefined. As soon as there is movement; time and space become relevant concepts that makes many other formula work.

Invoking the First law of thermodynamics, I believe is a mistake. But if you are committed to using English to contextualize all of existence; it's a mistake that you are forced to accept. English has a tendency to limit and flatten things out like on a piece of paper. Whereas the universe is all about motion (4D) besides the “Tremendous scale of existence” cannot fit on a piece of paper.

Funny break; (Mount Rushmore is in South Dakota) North Dakota does have a lot of ordinary rocks as well as a lot of cows.

FYI Galileo Galilei told us that the Earth moves.

Our current model of the solar system, on a flat piece of paper, leads us to think that the Earth revolves around the sun every 365 days. This promotes other implausible flat ideas and theories that must give stars a major role in the chemical composition of our tiny planet. This includes the idea that huge stars make all the heavier elements when they supernova, taking hundreds of thousand of years to cycle through each time (not to mention the huge variety of needed to produce the very heaviest elements) all within our local space and allowing gravity the time to slowly gather it all back together near our tiny solar system.
How can this fit with our tremendous scale of existence? Let me ask is this star dust idea the direct product of the flat solar system model, where is all the motion and vastness when talking about the path of the earth following the sun?

Kepler space telescope has revealed a mind numbing number of planets. WOW that's truly amazing, my mind was numb before you told me that fact. Such large numbers much like Carl Sagan and his ... billions and billions.

The popular theory of stellar evolution, as seen on PBS, has one huge, often not talked about flaw. How can 4.567 billion year old earth rocks yield material evidence of variable ages (specifically the many radioactive transition metals; some having their half-life measured in thousands of years; take a closer look at Holmium). Where is the true origin of these unstable and changing elements, common answer from PBS Cosmology is that it all started in some ancient 13.8 billion year old clump of stardust. The much more scientifically plausible answer remains unknown and thus unspoken.

Take the solar system off of the flat piece of paper and you will see a universe in motion. In ten billion years our sum will move through space along a relatively small cross section of our galaxies spiral arm, pulling earth along with it, with this motion in mind in the past 4.567 billion years we have never passed the same point in space twice. It is understated that our entire universe is in motion on a tremendous scale.

11:08 Wikipedia: The Friedmann–Lemaître–Robertson–Walker (FLRW) metric is an exact solution of Einstein's field equations of general relativity; it describes a homogeneous, isotropic expanding or contracting universe that is path connected, but not necessarily simply connected.[1][2][3] The general form of the metric follows from the geometric properties of homogeneity and isotropy; Einstein's field equations are only needed to derive the scale factor of the universe as a function of time. Depending on geographical or historical preferences, a subset of the four scientists — Alexander Friedmann, Georges Lemaître, Howard P. Robertson and Arthur Geoffrey Walker — may be named (e.g., Friedmann–Robertson–Walker (FRW) or Robertson–Walker (RW) or Friedmann–Lemaître (FL)). This model is sometimes called the Standard Model of modern cosmology,[4] although such a description is also associated with the further developed Lambda-CDM model. The universe is his workshop. Scientists are like children discovering dad's tools and exploring what he keeps in those mysterious jars on the top shelves. To claim that "there was nothing before the big bang...except for that singularity" violates causality, for one, and it's also pretty untenable.
I can't think of anything that just pops into existence out of nowhere, even subatomic particles need a context in order to exist, they are subjected to causality too.
If there was a singularity, then there was already something before the big bang, and that something was a product of causality.
A "scenario" had to be already there in order for that singularity to even exist.
All those physicists who claim that there was absolutely nothing before the big bang seem to be trapped in a technicality.
When I say "before the big bang" I'm thinking about causality (one thing leads to another, cause and effect), so what I'm really asking is what caused that singularity in the first place. If the best answer those physicists can provide is "it just was" or "there was no causality before the big bang, there was just a singularity", then they find themselves in the same place as all the religions in the world.
There's a gap in their knowledge that seems hopeless and they surrender instead of trying to think out of the box. But not all physicists share that vision, there are others who think that the big bang wasn't a singular event, big bangs could be happening all the time, there are different cosmological models, some of them are called "cyclic", some of those claim that the universe expands, contracts, bounces and expands again, etc., some others claim that the big bang was originated by the collision of "branes".
So, according to those cyclic models, there was definitely something "before" the big bang, btw, all those models are based on math and are compatible with the concept of the big bang.
In any case, the mere existence of different models suggests that we are pretty clueless regarding this matter.

What's clear to me is that modern physics is still a discipline in its infancy, we have still plenty of things to discover, correct, and relearn.

I knew most of this material before watching but I think reacquainting yourself with something you already know can sometimes generate new understanding and a different perspective. Two thoughts occurred to me that hadn't before. The first, is if the Earth is 4.5 billion years and the Big Bang was 13.8, than any star system born less than 4.5 billion but being further away than 4.5 billion light years would eventually be appearing in our night sky. Statistically doesn't it seem feasible that we should be seeing new stars on a fairly regular basis? In a couple billion years could our night sky be brighter? Is it brighter than when Galileo was looking at it? Are there planets where the night sky has so many stars that night is just as bright as day? If we see more stars will we learn things we never imagined?

My second thought is more philosophical. I can listen to the same set of facts from 10 different sources, each agreeing on the details of the facts. However each one can put a different spin or emphasis. Each one could connect sets of facts in different ways. Really important; each one has it's own set of biases. I basically learn 10 views of the same story, then I apply my personal experience and related bits of knowledge, and unfortunately my unconscious bias' and I end up creating my own personal view of the facts everyone is repeating. So same facts but 11 different views of them. A long time ago I recognized this and because of it I try to look for different sources of the same material to hopefully get closer to a real understanding. However that bias thing is an issue. I don't know how you get around the bias factor unless maybe you acknowledge it and people starting talking more about why you believe instead of what you believe.

Please read this post, and it clarifies the question, "What happened before the big bang?"

Imagine standing at the north pole. If I told you to walk north, east or west you would tell me that you can't, you are as far north as you could possibly be, and there's no frame of reference to walk east or west. If I told you to walk in any direction one foot, then you would be one foot from the north pole. Afterwards, if I told you to walk 2 feet north, you would tell me that's impossible, but, if I told you to face north, and walk two feet in that direction, you would be on the mirror side of the pole, but once again, one foot away. Now let's use this concept with time, as space and time are linked up, and my explanation could now be extrapolated to time because of this. The Big Bang is the north pole. Start one minute after the Big Bang, go two minutes towards the Big Bang. Once again, you would be one minute from the Big Bang. The way our species perceives time, if we were to do this, we would be swept up and begin traveling through time in the opposite direction we are now. (This next piece is my interpretation of this) All the antimatter is in that direction. It is the mirror reality. For us, if we were to go to the moment before the Big Bang from our direction, we would be approaching nothingness, just as if the mirror versions of ourselves approached it. Now if you are versed in Calculus, you can see this as we are the right sided limit, and they are the left sided limit. Now I don't think there can be negative people, but we know that space has three dimensions. Space also must have three dimensions then. The Big Bang is the point from which a concentric sphere bubbles out, with all possible realities contained within it. There is no before a center of a circle, but the diameter would be twice as long as our own Universes time. I would argue that the span of time that our Big Bang currently covers is 13.8 billion years times squared, times pi, but also constantly getting bigger.

Call me a skeptic if you want, but I still have a problem with the big bang theory, specifically with the first law of thermodynamics. If matter/energy cannot be created or destroyed but only change forms, then that would mean that an entire universe of energy existed in an almost infinitesimally small point. But it couldn't have just been arbitrarily created. Somehow, that energy existed before the big bang. Before spacetime? Where could that have come from? How could energy exist before space and time? And what kicked off the reaction? One of Newton's laws says that an object at rest or motion tends to stay in that state until acted upon by an outside force. Where was the first domino that started it all?

It's really not the idea of the universe suddenly beginning at once that throws me. Heck, even scientists and Christians pretty much agree with that idea, just with different visions of it. But this is such a big plot hole to me that I can't fully accept the idea of the big bang as any more than a theory, not a scientific law as some might pretend.

Oh, minor physics correction here: it turns out the BICEP II experiment didn't confirm the inflation hypothesis and just sort of jumped the gun on publishing their results. What they thought was the signature of inflation was actually dust. If you don't believe me, see what the fine folks at Nature have to say:

http://www.nature.com/news/full-galaxy-dust-map-muddles-search-for-gravitational-waves-1.15975
http://www.nature.com/news/gravitational-wave-team-admits-findings-could-amount-to-dust-1.15440

The first link includes work done in part by members of BICEP II, effectively refuting their widely publicized results. This neither proves nor rules out inflation, and cosmologists are still (generally) big fans of the idea. These results just mean that peer review works.

The thing that always bothered me with big bang theory is that all our models in physics, as they are formulated now, have only been validated within our recently recorded human history. (Approximately few thousands of years to be generous.)

Can we really confidently apply our current models to timespans orders of magnitude larger than what we ever observed? In the same way that classical physics broke its teeth when dealing with stuff orders of magnitude too small, are we sure that our current models can really chew stuff orders of magnitude older than us?

THE BEGINNING
The material heavens and earth are created.—Genesis 1:1.
DARKNESS
The earth is formless, desolate, and dark.—Genesis 1:2.
FIRST DAY
Diffused light evidently penetrates the earth’s atmosphere. If there had been any observer on the surface of the earth, the sources of light would have been imperceptible to him. Yet, the difference between night and day became discernible.—Genesis 1:3-5.
SECOND DAY
The earth is covered with water and a dense mantle of vapor. These two elements are separated, creating a gap between the watery surface and the canopy of vapor. The Bible describes this space as “an expanse between the waters,” and calls it “Heaven.”—Genesis 1:6-8.
THIRD DAY
Surface water subsides and dry ground appears. The atmosphere clears up to allow more sunlight to reach the ground. Some vegetation appears, with new species sprouting through the third and subsequent creative days.—Genesis 1:9-13.
FOURTH DAY
The sun and moon become discernible from the earth’s surface.—Genesis 1:14-19.
FIFTH DAY
God creates underwater creatures and flying creatures in great numbers with the ability to procreate within their kinds.—Genesis 1:20-23.
SIXTH DAY
Land animals are created, both large and small. The sixth day culminates with a masterpiece of God’s physical creation: the first human couple.—Genesis 1:24-31.

To add an explanation about this background microwave radiation:
In the beginning there was an electron soup, because electrons were not bound to atoms, and it was an opaque medium trapping radiation. As soon as the atoms formed, radiation was free to travel. It was very high energy radiation (like gamma and beyond), and very intense.
Now, the universe is expanding, and the expansion is accelerating. Because of that, some of the radiation did not reach us yet, and its waves are constantly being lengthened by the ever-expanding space. The space expansion speed can exceed the speed of light, at which point we will have no way to detect anything coming from a region of space that's moving away from us at that speed. But before that, we will detect the Electromagnetic waves, at a much longer wave length (lower energy).
This is why, the microwave radiation (long wave compared to the original wave length) is the only radiation coming from that distant past, from distant regions of space. It is the very first light to break the opaque electron soup, which marks the birth of the first atoms.

And we are lucky. Because we are at the brink of detecting it. Had we developed slower, like a few million years slower, we would not have observed this picture, and would have no information about the Big Bang. Our distant descendants will have nothing except our own documented measurements, on this matter.

And what does this picture really tells us? Well, the background radiation is very uniform, because matter and energy distribution was very uniform at that time. It was the tiny quantum fluctuations that caused instabilities, that formed centers of gravity that attracted ever more matter, to form the galaxies, and eventually the stars, and planets that we have today. So the images we got of those fluctuations have a very high contrast, to highlight those ripples. Because information can only travel with the speed of light, and we know the age of that light, we know how big those clumps of matter should really be, depending on the shape of the universe. This picture, thus, provides us with answers to questions about the shape of the universe, whether it's infinite or not, and what will happen to it eventually.

It is one of the most important measurements in cosmology.

So I've been watching these videos since the first World History videos were posted and so far I would say that I have always found these videos to be quite accurate; however, I feel that I should help clear up a small misconception: The Big Bang is a scientific theory, not history. I realize that I will most likely catch flack in the comments from this, but assuming that we know what happened in space about 7 billion years ago is a little hubris don't you think? I'm fine for having a theory about what happened and how the universe started, but you can't teach a theory as fact.

I'm currently an agnostic/debating to become a non-denominational Christian majoring in biomedical engineering and minoring in quantum mechanics, and I've noticed that as I read through my biology textbooks, I start to become more intrigued and more skeptical of how we were made.

With science constantly being updated, I can't help but wonder this:

1. Why do we (humans) exist? Think about it: We pretty much b*tch-slap evolution in the face by helping the weak, preventing Darwinian evolution from occurring due to the "fittest" people often helping the "unfit" to become "fit" (remember that evolution occurs in a population, not an individual.)
2. We are the only species on Earth that can literally wipe out 3/4 of all species of life on Earth at whim due to how intelligent we are.
3. Chimpanzees, our closest ancestors, are considered geniuses for opening their own cages when given the key, yet we humans still call each other stupid when we are really the most intelligent life forms on Earth. Why?

If anyone has an answer, please let me know, as I am very curious as to how we went from stupid orangutan, to stupid ape, to slightly less stupid chimpanzee, to TRAVELING TO ANOTHER FUCKING PLANET humans.

This may be a little nit-picky, but isn't it currently theorized that the Universe is (probably) infinite, therefore the statement that the Universe started as a tiny point a fallacy? I think I understand what you're trying to get at that 'before' the start of the Big Bang, space, time, and spacetime weren't really properties of the Universe, thus discussing things in term of size and volume doesn't make any real sense.

But if I understand this correctly, (which I probably don't) wouldn't it be more accurate to say that at the time of the Big Bang, the Universe was unimaginably dense as opposed to unimaginably small, and simply expanded everywhere simultaneously thereafter?

I think this video would probably lead to people believing that the celestial bodies we see that are 13.8 billion light years away are at the edge of a finite Universe, which is simply not the case. We can actually see objects up to 46 billion light years away even though they started moving away 13.8 billion years ago because space is expanding faster than light can travel. Over a longer period of time, we'll be able to see more, but we'll most likely never be able to see all of it.

If I somehow misunderstood something, I'd like to know, I've been trying to wrap my mind around this subject for a looong time.

Here's what I think, feel free to mock me. We only know what we can experience, and many people claim they only believe in things that they have physical proof for. So then, we have no physical proof of intelligence. We have no physical proof of a number. Numbers are abstract concepts. Good is an abstract concept. The idea of eternal patterns or immortal beings, depending on what you believe? Abstract. Opinions about any of these things? They're all abstract. You can't point to an opinion. You can reference a person, a concrete concept, who makes an opinion. You can point to an apple and call it an "apple" or "la manzana" or whatever you call it in your preferred language. 

There is nothing wrong with the abstract. It's awesome. There are whole thought processes that deal with the abstract. There's a lot that we don't understand, but we want to know more, so we keep going, and I don't think that's for naught. But I also don't think we can for sure say that any of us are right about anything. Hell, I don't even know if everything I said is true. I do know one thing: we can't know everything, but we can make it easier on ourselves by accepting what we don't know. Abstractly, I mean. Like, there's no one definition of 'good' or 'image' or 'blue,' even. Everyone's a little different, but we're capable of agreeing on some things or at least talking them over. Rather than bitching at each other about being wrong, offer your opinion and support it with actual evidence. 

Calm your tits, guys. 

There's something incredible about what we don't know. It's exciting, and we want to be able to learn more and more, but we have to keep in mind that we're not gonna understand the universe. If we did, it'd be kinda boring. What science does is provide a kind of background. "There's nothing here to argue against, [science] is a process, not an ideology," said Hank Green himself. It's. Not. An. Ideology. Atheism is not pro-science, theism is not anti-freedom of thought. 

Do something out of creative freedom and come back when you understand why the universe is fucking awesome and terrifying and oddly comforting.

I like most of the video, it brings a lot of what is a complicated topic into an easy to consume manner. However at about 5:30 you say there is no time before the Big Bang, which strictly speaking isn't true simply because it didn't exist in the sense it does in our established universe that it didn't exist. That's a problem with the tools used to understand it moreso than the concept. Time itself is basically what resolves chance, there is constantly finite causes and several more possible effects (down to quantum mechanical factors) cascading throughout the universe, time in a stream resolves all these. We currently measure time by it's visible effects on energy and matter because that is the simplest way for us to do so, and for the most part it seems to be constant in it's procession in a straight line at a steady pace on Earth. To say that is true for the entirety of the universe is false, as is it to say it for outside of it.

For example light being a brilliant "measurement" of time in that it always travels at the same speed relative to time. Light doesn't always move at the same "speed" though, we've observed that high gravity density can "slow" it down, and that matter that approaches the speed of light will always have light move the speed of the light "faster" than it. Both of these pose problems for the perception that time moves at a fixed pace. Because it either does and the speed of light isn't the speed of light, or the perception of time is relevant to gravatic density and speed, and more than likely other factors. That all fits with space time because there's more chances being resolved in an area denser in matter and energy.

Before the Big Bang supposing actual "nothingness" was ironically and perhaps confusingly "everything" doesn't mean time didn't exist, just that our method for measuring it doesn't work because all of the things and rules we use to measure it before that point didn't exist. If anything it would've moved infinitely faster because anything conceivable (and plenty not) would have been technically possible in infinite nothing for an infinite amount of time, time would still go on deciding which of these many myriad possibilities would occur and from then what. If you draw a continuous line on a piece of paper in whatever fashion you want, straight/squiggly/intricate/whatever as long as it's continuous. Then continue that line onto a piece of graph paper where (for the purposes of simplifying the analogy) the line now must be straight, continuous, and move from one side of the page to the other. You now have a graph against which to measure the progress of the line, you can now observe the rules by which it's now following and make assumptions within the graph about how it should and will move. The graph paper is our universe it's matter, energy, and the rules they (usually) abide by, the original piece is outside the universe (before/after/outside the possible boundaries of but that's a whole different game). To say because the line moves a particular way on the graph paper means it would on the original would be logical, until you realize the graph may be a much smaller sample size compared to the original. To say the line didn't exist before the graph is just as silly just because your current means of measuring the line don't work on the other piece of paper.

TL;DR Just because our means for measuring the perception of the passage of time as short lived beings of organic matter and energy don't work outside a universe of matter and energy on scopes most can't conceive, doesn't mean that time magically stops existing when it's inconvenient for us to figure out. You don't use kitchen scales to measure the frequency of light waves.

I really like what you guys are doing with the "World History" and  "American History" segments--they are AMAZING!  Although, when it comes to big history, I think people are really trying to FORCE this big bang thing in there.  I've watched a lot of video on this subject, and they all have different views of what happened--from the classic big bang like you've described (which does not mathematically "add up"), to the multi-verse collision idea (which ultimately delays, but raises the same questions).  There is a lot of uncertainty about the details, but the common element (assumption) through most of them is that the universe is obviously a result of  purely physical interactions.  

Unfortunately, if that is the case, no person has free-will.  We are only allowed to do those things which the particles, and thus atoms, and thus chemicals in our bodies allow us to do--our conciousness is just riding the wave of these interactions.  Following that logic, no one can be morally responsible for her/his behavior.  However, we do hold people morally responsible for their actions, but why??? I'm not a theoretical physicist, but it seems to me that we were created for a specific reason by a specific person to behave in a specific way.  

The more I learn about physics, the more the Bible's account of creation seems to become more obvious to me.  Since God gives me life, I can have free will, I can exist as a moral agent, and I am morally responsible to act according to His standard.  I'm not writing this to insult anyone.  It just seems to me that the entire big bang is supported by such a large amount of speculation, and people place so much of the other parts of their belief system upon this, that it makes me wonder why?  Why will people believe we came from monkey-like ancestors, shrew-like ancestors, and ultimately from a rock?  There remains another huge "????"  Why did life arise from non-life, and how did it happen?  Answer in short:  "no one knows, but it had to have happened, because you're here, right?"  BUT WHY???  I don't mean "how," because obviously no one knows "for sure" at this point.  I mean "WHY?"  Why does evolution, in it's classical sense, have to be true?  What does it take away from you?

The history of the Universe is not our history: Human history. 

Yes, yes, they are related, but by that very argument, everything is everything. Astrology is Art, Philosophy is Economics, and Hunny boo boo is quantum mechanics, and by this line of thinking, you cannot mention one particular without detailing the ways in which it is related to all other things. But how important is it really, to my knowledge of say, the rock cycle as it pertains to Cave painting? Sure, we couldn't have had those caverns without said process, but its no on my "need-to-know" list when attempting to analyse primitive man's ability to use abstract reasoning and creativity to illustrate a wall.

Simply because a field of study explains one subset of a subject, does not mean it is sufficient to be included within the preview of the collective entirety which makes up that 'expert field'. To remain relevant division in study, the lines must be drawn clearly, and it's scope of inquiry, limited to precisely what is subject is, through the exclusion of what it is not. 

These seemingly narrow restrictions may seem arbitrary, and one might even say, create more problems for our attempts to attain "true, justified, beliefs", however how helpful is it to know the pieces of an idea (the genetic ancestry of a rose bush, The risk to public safety of a rose bush, the aesthetic value of a Rose bush, the medicinal use of a Rose bush, etc...) without first having a grasp of what that thing IS. In this case, whatever is most essential about a rose bush. In fact, all our perceptions are limited by the stimulus are mind automatically filters- without our even being aware, the amount of information we may apprehend is cut down to the most basic, our thinking should be no exception. 

All things disciplines are ultimately lingual frameworks- physics doesn't exist independent of our thinking. (There is no gravity apart from our description of the effect we observe.) It is a selection of words composed into meaningful sentences which use to describe states of affairs. 

Inter-disciplinary studies by the way, are a thing that is done. This might fall under "our cosmological understanding of the nature of the universe and it's impact on the course of human history" -Which by category is  philosophy, physics, cosmology, and history respectively. So if your going to do something like that, you should first establish your methods and be transparent about what your video is trying to accomplish.

When talking about dark matter, a thought crossed me. Dark matter is said to be matter that we can't see, but we know that it's there because of it's gravitational effects, so there simply has to be some kind of matter there. 
But that got me thinking, gravity is explained as the attractive force caused by the bending of space-time caused by the presence of matter. So if space-time was a fabric,  matter would cause a curving in that fabric, a dip that matter would fall into. What if dark matter isn't a matter, but instead wrinkles in space-time itself! what if space-time isn't inherently smooth, but the force and cooling of the big bang itself caused the space-time to be wrinkled, creating natural gravitational wells in it. Those gravity-wells are what we see as dark matter, since it's a gravitational effect on the matter surrounding it, but without any matter to cause that gravity. it's a gravitational force caused by naturally occurring bending of space-time, originating from the very moment of the big bang.

I can understand why some people critique and have a hard time accepting the Big Bang Theory and Evolution. For them, I can draw a somewhat similar analogy with our historical knowledge about Gravity. It' is not the best analogy out there but I hope it gives some insight. 

The information we currently know about the origins of our Universe aka the Big Bang currently is similar to Issac Newton's Theory of Gravitation. The Big Bang Theory provides a somewhat explanation of what happened similar to Newtons laws which demonstrated what happens to planets and celestial beings when they are in orbit around a star. It predicts how they move and why they have elliptical orbits.

His equations also still hold good while sending rockets into space and attain orbit, but cannot be used to predict blackholes or questions like what would happen if the sun suddenly disappeared. In brief, it is more "observational" in a sense. 

What most critics of the Big Bang are looking for is similar to the Einstein's Theory of Relativity for Gravity, (since this involves the origins of our cosmos and we humans always wondered the "WHY" are we here question); which gives detailed information as how really gravity works in curving space-time, the cosmic speed limit i.e the mechanism of its working. Unfortunately, we do not know that yet about the Big Bang since our equations break down before that moment.

Yet, it does not in any way mean that we have in our model of the Big Bang is incorrect. It provides an explanation on what happened, the how is awaiting to be discovered and that pursuit is what we should focus on rather than conducting postmortems on already concrete conclusions. 

Not really good at analogies but I hope that helped.

Just from reading a handful of comments, I have to rant about the way people exploit scientific humility.  Good scientists will readily admit when theories aren't complete, but that doesn't mean there isn't a tremendous amount of evidence supporting those theories.  Whether it's the big bang, evolution, or global warming, there is always somebody who says, "well, scientists don't know for sure about everything, so they could be wrong, so... [make up something based on an anecdote, falsifiable book, or invalid extrapolation from personal experience].

When there is a consensus among the scientific community (which is made up by people who have spent there LIVES researching their fields), that means there is a plethora of corroborating evidence.  To the people who speculate about scientists "making up" the big bang to avoid an explanation for God, where did you get the idea that a group of people will so readily concoct phony theories to explain away things they don't like?  Is it because that's what you're doing right now?

But how do we know the big bang was the creation of space and time and not merely an event in a preexisting, larger universe? Where does eternal inflation fit into this? Will any of my comments on any of these videos actually get an answer?

The world may never know.

"The Big Bang" is somewhat of a misnomer. A more appropriate term would be "inflationary cosmology". Inflationary cosmology is a theory that sits happily with theistic and secular worldviews (providing you don't happen to think that everything -- including all your memories -- were created a second ago). In fact, inflationary cosmology was first theorized by a devout catholic, long before evidence for it was gathered.
Here are just two possibilities
Theistic: A timeless, changeless, all powerful god-concept somehow willed, or caused, or in some other fashion orchestrated the inflationary event outside of spacetime.
Secular: A timeless quantum field which undergoes eternal flux happens to generate matter and anti matter in -- usually -- equal portions, but in our case (and in perhaps others) happened to "spit out" more matter than anti matter which would then inflate.

Both explanations beg some pretty huge questions which only speak to the gaps in human knowledge, and -- to be honest -- we may never be able to test for either of these hypotheses. While naturalistic (secular) hypotheses are typically supported by mathematics and our previous findings through the scientific method, there are still problems with them, and naturalistic hypotheses will compete with each other for which most accurately predicts what we have seen and will see in the future. Theistic hypotheses tend to make more vernacular sense, however they generally tend to raise more questions than they answer up to and until persons x, y, and z decide to take their base assumption (a necessary god concept exists) for face value.

Whichever route you choose, at this point, speaks more to what evidence and/or arguments you find more compelling, and less to what may or may not actually exist. If (and only if) we decide to give into the (very) loaded language of the question "what caused the big bang?" or "what happened before the big bang?" or "why is there stuff rather than nothing?" or what have you, the only intellectually honest answer from both theist and atheist alike would be "nobody knows".

Ultimately, it does not matter what underlying worldview one has -- inflationary cosmology has effectively risen above a hypothesis to scientific theory. It might all be BS... but then again, we might all be under the spell of some crazy trickster-god and everything we know might be wrong as well. At the end of the day, all worldviews would do well to incorporate this theory into their understanding of (what might as well be) reality in order to maintain some degree of relevance. It is not going away, and it explains an awful lot about what we observe (god or no).

It isn't really proven that space-time began at the Big Bang. That's just one of several leading cosmological theories. It's entirely possible that there was something "before" the Big Bang. One theory that's been popular in recent years is "eternal inflation," which basically hypothesizes that the universe was undergoing inflation long before the Big Bang...possibly forever. In this theory, all of the matter/energy created in our little portion of the universe are a direct result of the inflation stopping. If this is correct, it would suggest that there are other universes in space-time located unimaginably far away from us, which may have different laws of physics.

Actually, that's the definition of history - "the stuff that's been written down." Before that we have 'prehistory.' So yes, at the advent of writing, history literally began then. Obviously, a lot of things happened before then, but our methods of studying them are fundamentally different... because there was nothing written about them by people. That's not to say that the study of prehistory is in any way inferior or unworthy, but it's not history.

13:34 -- This encapsulates my one big problem with this video, and the assumption behind the title: that no only is the definition of history settled, but that definition is simply "Stuff that happened in the past". This idea, in my book, is way, way sillier than "the Big Bang isn't History" (which, properly understood, is a perfectly reasonable point). In fact, the question of what the definition and purpose of history is (related concepts) is as old as the subject of history itself, but the simplistic idea that it is simply the study of the past tends to not hold water.

Imagine a closed system, like a box, that contains some items. Imagine that it's very cold in there and nothing is alive, moving or changing. If the contents of box stay neatly arranged, never moving, then from the perspective of inside the box time is standing still. The box has a low entropy state. The items in the box can spontaneously be moved around into a less ordered system but will not move back into the ordered state without outside work being done on it. Our perception of time mirrors transition from order to disorder in a system.

Entropy has been called the "arrow of time". Time is how we perceive the universe's increase in entropy.

time slows down as you approach the speed of light or in a strong gravitational field (or are in a very boring class).  If the universe is so dense (i.e. strong gravitational field), how does this impact time at the beginning of the big bang. 

As stated on another site:
Time slows down near any massive body; black holes are merely the most extreme example. GPS satellites orbiting the Earth have to correct for the fact that time passes very very slightly more slowly on the Earth's surface than it does in geosynchronous orbit -- by about one second per every 60 years.

In a sense, gravity and time dilation are the same thing: they are both consequences of the curvature of spacetime near a massive body. You can't have one without the other."

I just love the "but something can't come from nothing" religious response.. because okay, sure.. so something can't come from nothing? So.. the only possible explanation is that a creator had to make it? That intuitively sort of makes sense, until you realise.. what was BEFORE the creator? who created the creator? You're just pushing the problem away, not solving it. "God is infinite, he was always there" you say? Okay, how about the matter and energy in the universe was also "always" there and some reaction caused it to explode into the big bang, that's equally as plausible, if not more so.
I agree it sounds implausible that something comes from nothing, but we don't know what was "before" the big bang, or if there was the concept of time in which you can even have a "before" and "after", but the point is we just can't know. And to say there was a creator is just as arbitrary as it would be to say the universe was sneezed out by a giant goat, or that the universe is some mold growing on leftover curry in the back of someone's fridge. Actually, explaining colour to a blind person can be tackled from a wide range of approaches.  We can see from blue to red, blue is a low-frequency tone, red is a high-frequency tone.  (Association via sound equivalence.)  Red is 'warm', 'hot', 'spicy', 'fiery', and blue is 'cold', etc., etc.  (Association via connotation.)  And so forth.  By explaining it using sound equivalence a blind person would get a pretty accurate "vision" of how light works.  Blind and deaf would pose a continuing problem, however…

It may be worth mentioning in a future episode that the term "History" classically speaks of the time-frame following the invention of writing. Events occurring prior to written record are considered prehistory. In that sense, the Big Bang was not "the mother of all historical events", it was a prehistoric one. As this series will undoubtedly draw great audience for years to come, I think it is important to clarify this point.

"It was expanding form an unimaginably tiny point to an unimaginably large universe unimaginably quickly."
This statement is wrong. The universe did and still does expand, but it does not get "bigger".
When the universe was smaller than an Atom, it was the biggest thing to have ever existed. There was nothing to compare the universe to.
We call the Earth big, but what we are really saying is that the Earth is big relative to us. We say the Earth is small, but what we are really saying is that the Earth is small relative to the universe.
Words like big, small, and quickly do not belong in a statement that is about the universe. 
The speed of light is the fastest idea known to man, but it is infinity slow compared to the vastness winch is our universe, and the vastness winch is our universe is infinity small compared to the vastness witch may be our multiverce.

This is a rather brilliantly choreographed video. However one thing I think it gets across wrong is that the universe was never the size of an atom; the observable universe was. The big bang did not happen anywhere, it happened everywhere and the universe simply expanded from being very dense and infinitely large to being much more sparse and being infinitely large.

MinutePhysics' video on the big bang gives an excellent explanation of this and I encourage you to watch it as the concept is far better explained with diagrams.

Trying to explain the universe in a calendar is a good way to help describe the different epochs in cosmological history, but the calendar will always be limited & like a Geographical world map your poles or start and finish becomes highly distorted since your trying to use a grid to describe a spherical object while the laws of the Universe seem to change in different stages of the Cosmological evolution which explains why expansion could travel faster the speed of light the first second of the universe, slow down to nothing, & than constantly accelerate which is our present epoch.
